speaker: Verso
line: The 46 are nearby.

speaker: Lune
line: Here?

speaker: Verso
line: Yeah. But getting to them might be tricky.

speaker: Lune
line: When is it not?

speaker: Verso
line: Are they-

speaker: Lune
line: My parents? No. It’s Amélie and Christophe. They used to come by our house for dinner.

speaker: Verso
line: I’m sorry.

speaker: Lune
line: They were good people. (clears throat) Their journal must be around here.

speaker: Verso
line: You ok?

speaker: Lune
line: Let’s head back to camp.

speaker: Lune
line: All my life, everything we did was about the Paintress. It was a constant hum in the background. This worry, this responsibility, just… always there. Always… Always. Always. There was no relief. Never. Even when I sleep—It’s still there. Like a breath I can never release.

speaker: Verso
line: That’s a lot of pressure.

speaker: Lune
line: Even her last words were still—“Finish our work.”

speaker: Verso
line: It also shows how much faith she had in you.

speaker: Lune
line: That’s one way to look at it.

speaker: Verso
line: And the other way?

speaker: Lune
line: My only value to them. Not as a daughter, but as a backup plan. For their legacy.

speaker: Verso
line: You really believe that?

speaker: Lune
line: They always said, at the end of the game, there are no points for effort. Only results.

speaker: Verso
line: If you hate it so much, why continue their work at all?

speaker: Lune
line: I don’t know. Maybe because I still hear their voices in my head? And running away won’t silence them.

speaker: Verso
line: They’re dead. The voices aren’t theirs. They’re yours. Even if they were alive, the voices in your head, the voices you listen to, have to be your own.

speaker: Lune
line: … Is that how it works for you?

speaker: Verso
line: Getting there. Sometimes, it’s hard to tell.

speaker: Lune
line: Yeah.
